elements.content: In order to tune the Zn(II) coordination polymer architectures, three position isomers, 1,4- (pbtmb), 1,3- (mbtmb), and 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (obtmb), and flexible tetracarboxylate ligand, 5,5′-(1,4-phenylenebis(methylene))bis(oxy)diisophthalic acid (H4L1), were used to assemble compounds with different kinds of entangled networks, namely, {[Zn2(L1)(pbtmb)2]·4H2O} n (1), {[Zn2(L1)(mbtmb)2]·4H2O} n (2), and [Zn2(L1)(obtmb)2] n (3). Flexible bis(triazole) ligands present diverse conformations in these compounds. Compound 1 shows a 4-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional architecture with 4-connected mog (moganite) topology. Compound 2 displays a 2D + 2D → 3D polycatenation network simplified as new 4-connected topology with the Schlafli notation of {4,64;8}2{42,64}. Compound 3 is a 2D polythreading structure, in which two layed networks interpenetrate in a (2D/2D) parallel fashion. The powder X-ray diffraction, thermal stabilities, and the photoluminescence of 1–3 have also been investigated.

elements.content: Design and construction of coordination polymers with their intriguing topological structures and potential applications as functional solid materials have aroused great interest in chemists. In order to get such materials, the most effective and facile method is to employ the well-designed organic ligands as well as appropriate metal ions. Recently, a great number of multifunctional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been constructed. An attractive class of structures are the entangled systems, such as interpenetrated networks, polycatenated and polyknotted species, polythreading, and so on. The characteristics of various entangled systems have been well discussed in a comprehensive review by Ciani and co-workers. Accordingly, polycatenation can be described as a type of entanglement in which the component motifs have lower dimensionality than that of the resulting architectures, and each individual motif is catenated only with the adjacent ones, not with all the others, while the polythreading structures can be considered as extended periodic analogues of the molecular rotaxanes or pseudorotaxanes, with the existence of closed loops and rod or string elements that can thread through the loops.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and construction of coordination polymers with their intriguing topological structures and potential applications as functional solid materials have aroused great interest in chemists. In order to get such materials, the most effective and facile method is to employ the well-designed organic ligands as well as appropriate metal ions. Recently, a great number of multifunctional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been constructed. An attractive class of structures are the entangled systems, such as interpenetrated networks, polycatenated and polyknotted species, polythreading, and so on. The characteristics of various entangled systems have been well discussed in a comprehensive review by Ciani and co-workers. Accordingly, polycatenation can be described as a type of entanglement in which the component motifs have lower dimensionality than that of the resulting architectures, and each individual motif is catenated only with the adjacent ones, not with all the others, while the polythreading structures can be considered as extended periodic analogues of the molecular rotaxanes or pseudorotaxanes, with the existence of closed loops and rod or string elements that can thread through the loops.

elements.content: There are numerous examples of entangled coordination frameworks that are usually constructed from long rigid/flexible organic ligands. Flexible ligands are good candidates due to their conformational freedoms, while long rigid ligand can also be combined to construct diverse networks. The selection of rigid/flexible mixed ligands has been reported as a popular approach to construct novel frameworks with entangled structures, but it is rare that two flexible ligands are used. The reason may lie in that it is difficult to control the designed structure using two kinds of flexible ligands at the same time. However, it also provides an opportunity to understand the relationships between flexible ligands and the diverse structures they can produce and, especially, different kinds of entangled networks.

elements.content: In this work, we perform a comparative study on the tuning of entangled networks by using three isomers of bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene as bridging ligands in combination with flexible 5,5′-(1,4-phenylenebis(methylene))bis(oxy)diisophthalic acid (H4L1) (Scheme ) and zinc centers. Three new zinc compounds with three kinds of entanglement, {[Zn2(L1)(pbtmb)2]·4H2O} n (1), {[Zn2(L1)(mbtmb)2]·4H2O} n (2), and [Zn2(L1)(obtmb)2] n (3), have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. In addition, the spectroscopic, thermal, and fluorescence properties of complexes 1–3 are also investigated.

elements.content: The ligands 5,5′-(1,4-phenylenebis(methylene))bis(oxy)diisophthalic acid (H4L1),1,4-bis((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (pbtmb), 1,3-bis((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (mbtmb), and 1,2-bis((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (obtmb) were prepared according to the literature. All other chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) were performed on a Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer by KBr pellets in the range 400–4000 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analyses (TG-DTA) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. The photoluminescent (PL) spectra were recorded on a HORIBA Jobin-Yvon FluoroMax-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The luminescent data were investigated in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

The ligands 5,5'-(1,4-phenylenebis(methylene))bis(oxy)diisophthalic acid (H4L1),1,4-bis((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (pbtmb), 1,3-bis((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (mbtmb), and 1,2-bis((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene (obtmb) were prepared according to the literature. All other chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) were performed on a Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra (IR) were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer by KBr pellets in the range 400-4000 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses (TG-DTA) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. The photoluminescent (PL) spectra were recorded on a HORIBA Jobin-Yvon FluoroMax-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The luminescent data were investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.15 mmol), H4L1 (0.023 g, 0.05 mmol), pbtmb (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol), H2O (3 mL), and acetonitrile (3 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL), which was heated at 120 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. Colorless rodlike crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 40% for 1 (0.023 g, based on H4L1). Anal. Calcd for C48H46O14N12Zn2: C, 50.32; H, 4.05; N, 14.67%. Found: C, 50.26; H, 4.43; N, 14.84%. elements.content: The single-crystal structure data for compounds 1–3 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct method with SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their calculated positions. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1, .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal structure data for compounds 1-3 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct method with SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included at their calculated positions. The crystal data and structure refinement results are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1, .

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Infrared Spectra

In the IR spectra of compounds 1-3, the absence of absorption bands at 1720-1670 cm-1 in 1-3 indicates the H4L1 ligand adopts the completely deprotonated L1 4- form. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups are observed in the ranges of 1626-1572 cm-1 and 1417-1329 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 1 presents a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture with 4-connected mog topology. The asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent ZnII atom, half a L1 ligand, a pair of half pbtmb ligands, and two water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each ZnII atom is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two pbtmb ligands and two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands, showing a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Zn–N bond lengths are 2.020(2) and 2.040(3) Å, and Zn–O bond lengths fall in the range of 1.947(2)–1.969(2) Å. The L1 ligand is fully deprotonated and acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect four Zn ions. As the center of the central phenyl ring situated on an inversion center, two isophthalic rings are coplanar, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 81.73(2)°. The two pbtmb ligands show different coordination geometries in compound 1: although the two triazole rings of them are all parallel with each other, the separating distances are different, one is of 1.607 Å and the other is of 4.604 Å. The triazole rings in the pbtmb ligand all present anti mode, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 63.99(2)° and 79.71(2)°, respectively. As shown in Figure S1, , Zn(II) centers are bridged by pbtmb ligands to yield a 1D zigzag chain with Zn···Zn separation of 15.0221(3) Å. Finally, these chains are further connected by L1 ligands toward different directions to generate a 3D structure with nanosized, rectangle channels viewed along the a axis (Figure b). The average separation of the adjacent Zn···Zn is about 15.02 × 33.87 Å, and a single tunnel is illustrated in Figure S2, . The voids in the framework are filled via mutual interpenetration of three more independent frameworks, generating a 4-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional architecture (Figure c). The independent nets in 1 are related by a single vector with different translation vectors of [0,1,0] (12.17 Å), which can all be assigned to the class Ia interpenetration. Despite this 4-fold interpenetration, there is still enough void space in the structure occupied by water molecules as guests. PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1260.5 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 13.8% of the unit cell volume (after the removal of the guest molecules).

Structure of {[Zn2(L1)(pbtmb)2]4H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent ZnII atom, half a L1 ligand, a pair of half pbtmb ligands, and two water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each ZnII atom is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two pbtmb ligands and two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands, showing a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Zn-N bond lengths are 2.020(2) and 2.040(3) Å, and Zn-O bond lengths fall in the range of 1.947(2)-1.969(2) Å. The L1 ligand is fully deprotonated and acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect four Zn ions. The two pbtmb ligands show different coordination geometries in compound 1: although the two triazole rings of them are all parallel with each other, the separating distances are different, one is of 1.607 Å and the other is of 4.604 Å. The triazole rings in the pbtmb ligand all present anti mode, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 63.99(2)° and 79.71(2)°, respectively. As shown in Figure S1, , Zn(II) centers are bridged by pbtmb ligands to yield a 1D zigzag chain with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 15.0221(3) Å. Finally, these chains are further connected by L1 ligands toward different directions to generate a 3D structure with nanosized, rectangle channels viewed along the a axis (Figure b). elements.content: With the mbtmb ligand instead of the pbtmb ligand, a new compound 2 with a distinct 2D double layer structure was obtained. The fundamental unit, shown in Figure a, contains one crystallographically independent Zn (II) cation, half L1 ligand, one mbtmb ligand, and two guest water molecules. Each Zn(II) atom displays a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two mbtmb ligands. Zn(II) centers are also bridged by mbtmb ligands to yield a 1D zigzag chain with Zn···Zn separation of 12.8816(3) Å (Figure S4, ). Two triazole rings in the mbtmb ligand present anti mode, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 54.24(3)° and 64.32(2)°, respectively. All carboxyl groups of L1 are also deprotonated in anti mode, and the dihedral angles between the side isophthalic rings and the central phenyl rings are 37.97(2)°. Each one is tetradentate ligand connecting four Zn ions, resulting in a 2D double layer motif with large free spaces (Figure b). As estimated by PLATON program, the potential solvent accessible void volume in 2 is 8.8%. Although large channels exist in the single double layer motif, they are interpenetrated by the identical bilayer motifs. The layers are perpendicular to [0,1,1] and stack as AAAA. Thus, the most fascinating structural feature of 2 is that each 4-connected 2D double layer motif, which is parallel to each other, is interlocked with the two nearest neighboring ones. Therefore, the resulting 3D array is an infinite polycatenation of the 2D double layer motif (Figure c). The catenation occurs between the vertical 4-membered and 6-membered rings (Figure S5, ). From the viewpoint of network topology, each Zn center and the L1 ligand can all be treated as a 4-connected node. Thus, the whole framework of 2 can be simplified as unprecedented 4-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of (4.64.8)2(42.64) as shown in Figure . The structure of 2 adopting such new topology might mainly be due to the presence of two kinds of flexible ligands.

elements.content: Some examples of polycatenated bilayers have also been reported, Li and co-workers synthesized the first 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation pattern constructed from a 4·82-fes network. Lu reported the new 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation of six-connected bilayer structure. [Cd(HO-BDC)(bpe)1.5] n (HO–H2BDC = 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid; bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl) ethane) features a 5-connected 2D → 3D polycatenation of the bilayer motif. To the best of our knowledge, such kind of 2D + 2D → 3D parallel polycatenation with 4-connected bilayer presented here is unprecedented.

elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, with an independent Zn(II) cation, a half L1 ligand, and one obtmb ligand in the asymmetric unit. Each Zn center in complex 3 also adopts a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry made up of two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two obtmb ligands (Figure a). Two flexible obtmb ligands all present syn mode to connect two Zn atoms forming the [Zn2(obtmb)2] loop with Zn···Zn separation of 8.9470(2) Å, and there is an inversion center located at the loop center. Two triazole-rings in the obtmb ligand both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 81.47(2)° and 82.41(3)°, respectively. Flexible L1 ligand is tetradentate ligand connecting four Zn ions, and the dihedral angle between the side isophthalic ring and the central phenyl ring is 53.01(2)°. Each [Zn2(obtmb)2] loop is linked by four L1 ligands to form a 2D layer (Figure b). In isolation, the network topology could be described as having the 3,4-connected network with the Schläfli notation of (4.62)2(42.62.82) (Figure c). The most interesting structural feature of 3 is that two such networks interpenetrate in a (2D/2D) parallel fashion to give rise to a 2D polythreading layer. Two [Zn2(obtmb)2] units bridged by two isophthalic rings of L1 ligands to form a larger loop of each net are threaded through by L1 ligand as a rod of the other layer and vice versa (Figure ). Polythreaded motifs can be regarded as periodically extended analogues of the molecular rotaxanes. Polythreaded coordination polymers are relatively rare because the systems require the presence of rings and rods that can thread the rings. One of the most famous examples is [Zn(1,4-bix)2(NO3)24.5H2O] n (1,4-bix = bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene) reported by Robson and co-workers, in which both the loop and rod elements are flexible 1,4-bix ligands. Following this, several mixed-ligand polythreaded-like networks containing flexible N-donors as loop linker and aromatic dicarboxylate as rods, such as [Zn(bmimbp)(tbtpa)] n (bmimbp = 4,4′-bis(2-methylimidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl; H2tbtpa = tetrabromoterephthalic acid) and [Cd(tp)(bpp)(H2O)H2O] n (H2tp = terephthalic acid; bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) were also reported. Among them, all the examples showing 2D–2D polythreaded array all consist of 2-membered loops, in which the flexible N-donor ligands always act as an annular linker motif and carboxylate anion act as linking rods, while in this compound the loop is made of two [Zn2(obtmb)2] units bridged by two isophthalic rings of L1 ligands instead of 2-membered loops. It has been shown that the variation of entanglement fashions in complexes 1–3 are mainly associated with the conformations of bis(triazole) ligands and the different spatial orientation of tetracarboxylate ligands. The combinations of these two factors are the key to influence the final entangled structures, which depends on the competition and adaptability of the components. In 1–3, although the tetracarboxylate ligand adopts similar coordination modes, their spatial orientations are quite different, which result in the variable dihedral angles between the side isophthalic rings and the central phenyl rings (Figure a–c). The dihedral angles is 81.73(2)° for compound 1, 37.97(2)° for compound 2, and 53.01(2)° for compound 3. The isomeric bis(triazole) ligands adopts completely different conformations of anti and syn in compounds 1–3 (Figure d–f), respectively. An anti conformation was found in compounds 1 and 2, while a syn conformation was in compound 3. The former contributes to the formation of a highly undulated sheet and the latter to the loop. These results show that isomer bis(triazole) ligand and the tetracarboxylate ligand can fine-tune themselves to match with the coordination preference of metal centers and lower the energetic arrangement in the self-assembly process.

Structure of [Zn2(L1)(obtmb)2] n  (3)

Complex 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, with an independent Zn(II) cation, a half L1 ligand, and one obtmb ligand in the asymmetric unit. Each Zn center in complex 3 also adopts a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry made up of two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two obtmb ligands (Figure a). Two flexible obtmb ligands all present syn mode to connect two Zn atoms forming the [Zn2(obtmb)2] loop with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 8.9470(2) Å, and there is an inversion center located at the loop center. Two triazole-rings in the obtmb ligand both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 81.47(2)° and 82.41(3)°, respectively. Flexible L1 ligand is tetradentate ligand connecting four Zn ions, and the dihedral angle between the side isophthalic ring and the central phenyl ring is 53.01(2)°. Each [Zn2(obtmb)2] loop is linked by four L1 ligands to form a 2D layer (Figure b). In isolation, the network topology could be described as having the 3,4-connected network with the Schläfli notation of (4.62)2(42.62.82) (Figure c). The most interesting structural feature of 3 is that two such networks interpenetrate in a (2D/2D) parallel fashion to give rise to a 2D polythreading layer. Two [Zn2(obtmb)2] units bridged by two isophthalic rings of L1 ligands to form a larger loop of each net are threaded through by L1 ligand as a rod of the other layer and vice versa (Figure ). Polythreaded motifs can be regarded as periodically extended analogues of the molecular rotaxanes. Polythreaded coordination polymers are relatively rare because the systems require the presence of rings and rods that can thread the rings. One of the most famous examples is [Zn(1,4-bix)2(NO3)24.5H2O] n  (1,4-bix = bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene) reported by Robson and co-workers, in which both the loop and rod elements are flexible 1,4-bix ligands. Following this, several mixed-ligand polythreaded-like networks containing flexible N-donors as loop linker and aromatic dicarboxylate as rods, such as [Zn(bmimbp)(tbtpa)] n  (bmimbp = 4,4'-bis(2-methylimidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl; H2tbtpa = tetrabromoterephthalic acid) and [Cd(tp)(bpp)(H2O)H2O] n  (H2tp = terephthalic acid; bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) were also reported. Among them, all the examples showing 2D-2D polythreaded array all consist of 2-membered loops, in which the flexible N-donor ligands always act as an annular linker motif and carboxylate anion act as linking rods, while in this compound the loop is made of two [Zn2(obtmb)2] units bridged by two isophthalic rings of L1 ligands instead of 2-membered loops. It has been shown that the variation of entanglement fashions in complexes 1-3 are mainly associated with the conformations of bis(triazole) ligands and the different spatial orientation of tetracarboxylate ligands. The combinations of these two factors are the key to influence the final entangled structures, which depends on the competition and adaptability of the components. In 1-3, although the tetracarboxylate ligand adopts similar coordination modes, their spatial orientations are quite different, which result in the variable dihedral angles between the side isophthalic rings and the central phenyl rings (Figure a-c). The dihedral angles is 81.73(2)° for compound 1, 37.97(2)° for compound 2, and 53.01(2)° for compound 3. The isomeric bis(triazole) ligands adopts completely different conformations of anti and syn in compounds 1-3 (Figure d-f), respectively. An anti conformation was found in compounds 1 and 2, while a syn conformation was in compound 3. The former contributes to the formation of a highly undulated sheet and the latter to the loop. These results show that isomer bis(triazole) ligand and the tetracarboxylate ligand can fine-tune themselves to match with the coordination preference of metal centers and lower the energetic arrangement in the self-assembly process.

elements.content:
Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) for complexes 1–3 were performed to characterize their purity (Figure S7, ). All the diffraction peaks on the curves are in good agreement with the simulated ones.

To estimate the stability of the coordination polymers 1–3, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments in the temperature range of 37–1000 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure ). No weight loss was found for compound 3 before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at about 270 °C. Compound 1 and 2 show the weight loss of 3.45% in 37–158 °C and 3.02% in 37–180 °C assigned to the release of four lattice water molecules (calcd 6.29% for 1 and 2); maybe the sample is partially dehydrate at room temperature. The decomposition of the frameworks occurred at about 350 and 313 °C, respectively. Then, the frameworks begin to collapse, accompanying the loss of organic ligands.

elements.content: The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1–3 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The emission peaks of these compounds are shown in Figure . The maximum emission peaks of compounds 1–3 are observed at 460 nm (λem = 350 nm) for 1, 416 nm (λem = 350 nm) for 2, and 482 nm (λem = 350 nm) for 3. Free pbtmb, mbtmb, obtmb, and L1 ligands fluoresced in the solid state with their emission peaks at 389, 378, 383, and 366 nm, respectively. In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maxima of compounds 1–3 show the obvious red shift. Because each compound contains ZnII ions, tetracarboxylate ligand, and flexible bis(triazole) ligands, it is truly difficult to assign its emissions as ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) transitions. Several factors might serve for the emissions, such as a change in the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energy levels of deprotonated carboxylate anions and neutral ligands coordinating to metal centers, and a joint contribution of the intraligand or charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and metal centers, as the Zn(II) ion are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d10 configuration. These emissions indicate the intraligand fluorescent emissions that are tuned by metal–ligand interactions and the deprotonated effect of the tetracarboxylate ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1-3 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The emission peaks of these compounds are shown in Figure . The maximum emission peaks of compounds 1-3 are observed at 460 nm (λem = 350 nm) for 1, 416 nm (λem = 350 nm) for 2, and 482 nm (λem = 350 nm) for 3. Free pbtmb, mbtmb, obtmb, and L1 ligands fluoresced in the solid state with their emission peaks at 389, 378, 383, and 366 nm, respectively. In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maxima of compounds 1-3 show the obvious red shift. Because each compound contains ZnII ions, tetracarboxylate ligand, and flexible bis(triazole) ligands, it is truly difficult to assign its emissions as ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) transitions. Several factors might serve for the emissions, such as a change in the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energy levels of deprotonated carboxylate anions and neutral ligands coordinating to metal centers, and a joint contribution of the intraligand or charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and metal centers, as the Zn(II) ion are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d10 configuration. These emissions indicate the intraligand fluorescent emissions that are tuned by metal-ligand interactions and the deprotonated effect of the tetracarboxylate ligand.

elements.content: Three new ZnII CPs have been prepared and structurally characterized. Structural comparisons indicate that the positions of the bis(triazole) building blocks play an important role in governing the structural topologies of these compounds, especially their different entangled networks. The results reveal interesting 4-fold interpenetrating with 4-connected mog (moganite) net, 2D + 2D → 3D polycatenation networks with unusual 4-connected topology, and (2D/2D) parallel polythreading fashion with new 3,4-connected net. The successful syntheses of these compounds provide new perspectives to design different kinds of entangled networks. Moreover, all compounds display fluorescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three new ZnII CPs have been prepared and structurally characterized. Structural comparisons indicate that the positions of the bis(triazole) building blocks play an important role in governing the structural topologies of these compounds, especially their different entangled networks. The results reveal interesting 4-fold interpenetrating with 4-connected mog (moganite) net, 2D + 2D → 3D polycatenation networks with unusual 4-connected topology, and (2D/2D) parallel polythreading fashion with new 3,4-connected net. The successful syntheses of these compounds provide new perspectives to design different kinds of entangled networks. Moreover, all compounds display fluorescent properties.

Colorless rodlike crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 40% for 1 (0.023 g, based on H4L1). Anal. Calcd for C48H46O14N12Zn2: C, 50.32; H, 4.05; N, 14.67%. Found: C, 50.26; H, 4.43; N, 14.84%. cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 presents a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture with 4-connected mog topology. The asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent ZnII atom, half a L1 ligand, a pair of half pbtmb ligands, and two water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each ZnII atom is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two pbtmb ligands and two oxygen atoms from two L1 ligands, showing a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Zn–N bond lengths are 2.020(2) and 2.040(3) Å, and Zn–O bond lengths fall in the range of 1.947(2)–1.969(2) Å. The L1 ligand is fully deprotonated and acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect four Zn ions. As the center of the central phenyl ring situated on an inversion center, two isophthalic rings are coplanar, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 81.73(2)°. The two pbtmb ligands show different coordination geometries in compound 1: although the two triazole rings of them are all parallel with each other, the separating distances are different, one is of 1.607 Å and the other is of 4.604 Å. The triazole rings in the pbtmb ligand all present anti mode, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 63.99(2)° and 79.71(2)°, respectively. As shown in Figure S1, , Zn(II) centers are bridged by pbtmb ligands to yield a 1D zigzag chain with Zn···Zn separation of 15.0221(3) Å. Finally, these chains are further connected by L1 ligands toward different directions to generate a 3D structure with nanosized, rectangle channels viewed along the a axis (Figure b). The average separation of the adjacent Zn···Zn is about 15.02 × 33.87 Å, and a single tunnel is illustrated in Figure S2, . The voids in the framework are filled via mutual interpenetration of three more independent frameworks, generating a 4-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional architecture (Figure c). The independent nets in 1 are related by a single vector with different translation vectors of [0,1,0] (12.17 Å), which can all be assigned to the class Ia interpenetration. Despite this 4-fold interpenetration, there is still enough void space in the structure occupied by water molecules as guests. PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1260.5 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 13.8% of the unit cell volume (after the removal of the guest molecules).

Thermal Analysis and PXRD Pattern

Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) for complexes 1–3 were performed to characterize their purity (Figure S7, ). All the diffraction peaks on the curves are in good agreement with the simulated ones.

To estimate the stability of the coordination polymers 1–3, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments in the temperature range of 37–1000 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure ). No weight loss was found for compound 3 before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at about 270 °C. Compound 1 and 2 show the weight loss of 3.45% in 37–158 °C and 3.02% in 37–180 °C assigned to the release of four lattice water molecules (calcd 6.29% for 1 and 2); maybe the sample is partially dehydrate at room temperature. The decomposition of the frameworks occurred at about 350 and 313 °C, respectively. Then, the frameworks begin to collapse, accompanying the loss of organic ligands.

The two pbtmb ligands show different coordination geometries in compound 1: although the two triazole rings of them are all parallel with each other, the separating distances are different, one is of 1.607 Å and the other is of 4.604 Å. The triazole rings in the pbtmb ligand all present anti mode, and both twist away from the central phenyl ring with dihedral angles of 63.99(2)° and 79.71(2)°, respectively. As shown in Figure S1, , Zn(II) centers are bridged by pbtmb ligands to yield a 1D zigzag chain with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 15.0221(3) Å. Finally, these chains are further connected by L1 ligands toward different directions to generate a 3D structure with nanosized, rectangle channels viewed along the a axis (Figure b). The average separation of the adjacent Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn is about 15.02 × 33.87 Å, and a single tunnel is illustrated in Figure S2, . The voids in the framework are filled via mutual interpenetration of three more independent frameworks, generating a 4-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional architecture (Figure c). The independent nets in 1 are related by a single vector with different translation vectors of [0,1,0] (12.17 Å), which can all be assigned to the class Ia interpenetration. Despite this 4-fold interpenetration, there is still enough void space in the structure occupied by water molecules as guests. PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1260.5 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 13.8% of the unit cell volume (after the removal of the guest molecules).

Thermal Analysis and PXRD Pattern

Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) for complexes 1-3 were performed to characterize their purity (Figure S7, ). All the diffraction peaks on the curves are in good agreement with the simulated ones.

To estimate the stability of the coordination polymers 1-3, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments in the temperature range of 37-1000 °C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (Figure ). No weight loss was found for compound 3 before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at about 270 °C. Compound 1 and 2 show the weight loss of 3.45% in 37-158 °C and 3.02% in 37-180 °C assigned to the release of four lattice water molecules (calcd 6.29% for 1 and 2); maybe the sample is partially dehydrate at room temperature. The decomposition of the frameworks occurred at about 350 and 313 °C, respectively. Then, the frameworks begin to collapse, accompanying the loss of organic ligands.
